On Wednesday 01 June 2005 20:48, Kevin Lawrence wrote:
> didoss@... wrote:
> > We have upwards of 10 developers working on ~1500 classes.  Our tests are
> > a pain to maintain - takes too long to run completely in Eclipse before
> > checking in; takes ~6 hours to run and report the nightlybuild (includes
> > coverage testing); we're nowhere near green bar, so recognizing when
> > there is something new (from yesterday) is near impossible, and possibly
> > impractical (in a 40 hour work week). I'm not necessarily looking for any
> > answers,...but maybe someone has some insight - has been there before -
> > or will just commisserate with me.  :)
>
> It's hard to imagine that unit tests for 1500 classes would take that long.
>
> Are you writing unit level tests ? Or system level tests ?
>
> What proportion of your tests hit a database/file system/network/gui ?

As a datapoint for comparison: Jena has about 1300 classes and about 4000
tests, and running those tests takes about 50s on my machine (a 3GHz Intel
beast with enough memory). We have five developers, but none of us is full-
time on Jena nowadays. 

The tests are a mixture of unit and integration tests, and touch the 
filesystem a little and the database not at all. Running the database
tests (which are a subset of the normal tests with the data store in
RDB rather than memory) takes more like 15m with MySQL and comparable 
or a lot longer with Postgres. (Likely because there's a complete
reset of the DB between each test.) Hence the DB tests get run a lot
less often, which is sort-of OK because they're "just" a storage layer
and so long as the DB presents the same (Graph) interface as memory
does, everthing else should "just work".
